where (i) is due to the fact that Jπ⋆≥Jπsuperscript𝐽superscript𝜋⋆superscript𝐽𝜋J^{\pi^{\star}}\geq J^{\pi}italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any policy π𝜋\piitalic_π, and the expectation fades due to uniform convergence. The only terms with a dependency on n𝑛nitalic_n are βn′⁢(δ)=O⁢(γ(H⁢n)12)subscriptsuperscript𝛽′𝑛𝛿𝑂superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐻𝑛12\beta^{\prime}_{n}(\delta)=O(\gamma_{(Hn)}^{\frac{1}{2}})italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_δ ) = italic_O ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Γn=O⁢(γ(H⁢n)⁢n−1)subscriptΓ𝑛𝑂subscript𝛾𝐻𝑛superscript𝑛1\Gamma_{n}=O(\gamma_{(Hn)}n^{-1})roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which can be combined in the asymptotic notation in the Theorem. If γn=O⁢(log⁡n)subscript𝛾𝑛𝑂𝑛\gamma_{n}=O(\log n)italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ), then Jπ⋆−Jπ=O⁢(n−12⁢log⁡n)→n→∞0superscript𝐽superscript𝜋⋆superscript𝐽𝜋𝑂superscript𝑛12𝑛superscript→→𝑛0J^{\pi^{\star}}-J^{\pi}=O(n^{-\frac{1}{2}}\log n)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle n\to% \infty}}{{\to}}0italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG → end_ARG start_ARG italic_n → ∞ end_ARG end_RELOP 0. For a summary of magnitudes of γnsubscript𝛾𝑛\gamma_{n}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for common kernels, we refer to Table 3 in Hübotter et al. (2024). ∎

Appendix B Guarantees in non-Lipschitz MDPs

The main result reported in Theorem 3 provides anytime guarantees on the agent’s performance, assuming smoothness in the MDP. However, it is possible to replace this assumption with a weaker one, at the cost of only retaining guarantees in expectation. This weaker version of the theorem can be retrieved by simply assuming smoothness on the noise, rather than on the MDP, and leveraging results recently presented by Maran et al. (2023).

Assumption 5.

The noise distribution ϵbold-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}bold_italic_ϵ is Lℓsubscript𝐿ℓL_{\ell}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-TV-Lipschitz continuous.

This assumption is satisfied by a large class of Gaussian and sub-Gaussian distributions (Maran et al., 2023). We can build upon Assumption 4 and Lemma 2, and start by providing a weaker version of Lemma 3.

Lemma 6.

(Uniform convergence of marginal variance in expectation) Under Assumption 1, for any n≥0𝑛0n\geq 0italic_n ≥ 0 and (s,c)∈𝒮×𝒞𝑠𝑐𝒮𝒞(s,c)\in\mathcal{S\times C}( italic_s , italic_c ) ∈ caligraphic_S × caligraphic_C,

𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)σn2⁢(s,c)≤2⁢σ¯2⁢Γnτmin2,subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛𝑠𝑐2superscript¯𝜎2subscriptΓ𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜏2min\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})}\sigma^{2}_{n}(s,c)% \leq\frac{2\bar{\sigma}^{2}\Gamma_{n}}{\tau^{2}_{\text{min}}},blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) ≤ divide start_ARG 2 over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where σ~2=max(s,c)∈𝒮×𝒞⁡σ02⁢(s,c)+ρ2⁢(s,c)superscript~𝜎2subscript𝑠𝑐𝒮𝒞subscriptsuperscript𝜎20𝑠𝑐superscript𝜌2𝑠𝑐\tilde{\sigma}^{2}=\max_{(s,c)\in\mathcal{S\times C}}\sigma^{2}_{0}(s,c)+\rho^% {2}(s,c)over~ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) ∈ caligraphic_S × caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) + italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) and τmin=mins,c∈𝒮×𝒞⁢𝔼τ∼𝛕⁢(c)𝟏s∈τsubscript𝜏minsubscript𝑠𝑐𝒮𝒞subscript𝔼similar-to𝜏𝛕𝑐subscript1𝑠𝜏\tau_{\text{min}}=\min_{s,c\in\mathcal{S\times C}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau% \sim\bm{\tau}(c)}\mathbf{1}_{s\in\tau}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_c ∈ caligraphic_S × caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

We resume from Inequality 60 in the proof of Lemma 3:

σn2⁢(s,c)≤2⁢σ¯2τmin2⁢𝔼c∼μcτ∼𝝉⁢(c)(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)∑t=0H−1ℐ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c);𝝅~⁢(τ,c)∣c1:n,τ1:n)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝑠𝑐2superscript¯𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝜏2minsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑐subscript𝜇𝑐similar-to𝜏𝝉𝑐similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℐ𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐conditionalbold-~𝝅𝜏𝑐subscript𝑐:1𝑛subscript𝜏:1𝑛\sigma_{n}^{2}(s,c)\leq\frac{2\bar{\sigma}^{2}}{\tau^{2}_{\text{min}}}\mathop{% \mathbb{E}}_{\begin{subarray}{c}c\sim\mu_{c}\\ \tau\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\\ (s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}\mathcal{I}(\bm{% \pi}(s_{t},c);\bm{\tilde{\pi}}(\tau,c)\mid c_{1:n},\tau_{1:n})italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) ≤ divide start_ARG 2 over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ; overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG ( italic_τ , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (79)

Therefore,

𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)σn2⁢(s,c)subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛𝑠𝑐\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})}\sigma^% {2}_{n}(s,c)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 2 over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ; overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG ( italic_τ , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (80)
≤maxc′∈𝒞⁢𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)τ′∼𝝉⁢(c′)c∼μc,(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)2⁢σ¯2τmin2⁢∑t=0H−1ℐ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c);𝝅~⁢(τ′,c′)∣c1:n,τ1:n)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑐′𝒞subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1similar-tosuperscript𝜏′𝝉superscript𝑐′formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑐subscript𝜇𝑐similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐2superscript¯𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝜏2minsuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℐ𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐conditionalbold-~𝝅superscript𝜏′superscript𝑐′subscript𝑐:1𝑛subscript𝜏:1𝑛\displaystyle\leq\max_{c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\begin{% subarray}{c}\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})\\ \tau^{\prime}\sim\bm{\tau}(c^{\prime})\\ c\sim\mu_{c},\;(s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\frac{2\bar{\sigma}% ^{2}}{\tau^{2}_{\text{min}}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}\mathcal{I}(\bm{\pi}(s_{t},c);\bm{% \tilde{\pi}}(\tau^{\prime},c^{\prime})\mid c_{1:n},\tau_{1:n})≤ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 2 over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ; overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (81)
=2⁢σ¯2⁢Γnτmin2.absent2superscript¯𝜎2subscriptΓ𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜏2min\displaystyle=\frac{2\bar{\sigma}^{2}\Gamma_{n}}{\tau^{2}_{\text{min}}}.= divide start_ARG 2 over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (82)

∎

Having bounded variance at each round, this time in expectation, we can invoke Lemma 4 to bound the expected distance to the optimal policy with high probability:

𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)‖π⋆⁢(s,c)−μn⁢(s,c)‖1≤βn′⁢(δ)⁢‖σ¯‖1⁢(2⁢Γnτmin2)12subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscriptnormsuperscript𝜋⋆𝑠𝑐subscript𝜇𝑛𝑠𝑐1subscriptsuperscript𝛽′𝑛𝛿subscriptnorm¯𝜎1superscript2subscriptΓ𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜏2min12\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})}\|\pi^{\star}(s,c)-% \mu_{n}(s,c)\|_{1}\leq\beta^{\prime}_{n}(\delta)\|\bar{\sigma}\|_{1}\Big{(}% \frac{2\Gamma_{n}}{\tau^{2}_{\text{min}}}\Big{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_δ ) ∥ over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 2 roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (83)

Instead of leveraging bounds for the imitator’s performance in Lipschitz-smooth settings, we can instead use the fact that the expert’s actions are corrupted by smooth noise. In this setting, it is instead possible to control the suboptimality of the imitator with respect to the noisy expert. We report the following Theorem from Maran et al. (2023), and refer to the original work for the proof.

Lemma 7.

Let π⋆superscript𝜋⋆\pi^{\star}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝛑~bold-~𝛑\bm{\tilde{\pi}}overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG and π𝜋\piitalic_π denote the expert, noisy expert and imitator policy, respectively. If Assumption 5 holds, then:

J𝝅~−Jπ≤2⁢Lℓ⁢Qmax1−γ𝔼s∼μ𝝅~[𝒲(π⋆(⋅∣s),π(⋅∣s))],J^{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}-J^{\pi}\leq\frac{2L_{\ell}Q_{\text{max}}}{1-\gamma}% \mathbb{E}_{s\sim\mu_{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}}[\mathcal{W}(\pi^{\star}(\cdot\mid s),% \pi(\cdot\mid s))],italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_W ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ∣ italic_s ) , italic_π ( ⋅ ∣ italic_s ) ) ] ,

where Qmax=max(s,c,a)∈𝒮×𝒞×𝒜⁡|Q⁢(s,a)|πsubscript𝑄maxsubscript𝑠𝑐𝑎𝒮𝒞𝒜superscript𝑄𝑠𝑎𝜋Q_{\text{max}}=\max_{(s,c,a)\in\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{A}}|% Q(s,a)|^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_c , italic_a ) ∈ caligraphic_S × caligraphic_C × caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q ( italic_s , italic_a ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}caligraphic_W represents the Wasserstein 1111-distance.

As the expert π⋆superscript𝜋⋆\pi^{\star}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the imitator πnsubscript𝜋𝑛\pi_{n}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both deterministic, this implies that

J𝝅~−Jnπ≤2⁢Lℓ⁢Qmax1−γ𝔼s∼μ𝝅~∥(π⋆(⋅∣s),π(⋅∣s))∥1.J^{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}-J^{\pi}_{n}\leq\frac{2L_{\ell}Q_{\text{max}}}{1-\gamma}% \mathbb{E}_{s\sim\mu_{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}}\|(\pi^{\star}(\cdot\mid s),\pi(\cdot% \mid s))\|_{1}.italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ∣ italic_s ) , italic_π ( ⋅ ∣ italic_s ) ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (84)

By invoking this Lemma, we can thus conclude that, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ

𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)J𝝅~−Jπn≤232⁢Lℓ⁢Qmax⁢‖σ¯‖1τmin⁢(1−γ)⁢βn′⁢(δ)⁢Γn12=O⁢(γ(H⁢n)⁢n−12).subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1superscript𝐽bold-~𝝅superscript𝐽subscript𝜋𝑛superscript232subscript𝐿ℓsubscript𝑄maxsubscriptnorm¯𝜎1subscript𝜏min1𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝛽′𝑛𝛿superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛12𝑂subscript𝛾𝐻𝑛superscript𝑛12\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})}J^{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}% -J^{\pi_{n}}\leq\frac{2^{\frac{3}{2}}L_{\ell}Q_{\text{max}}\|\bar{\sigma}\|_{1% }}{\tau_{\text{min}}(1-\gamma)}\beta^{\prime}_{n}(\delta)\Gamma_{n}^{\frac{1}{% 2}}=O(\gamma_{(Hn)}n^{-\frac{1}{2}}).blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_γ ) end_ARG italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_δ ) roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (85)

Therefore, if γn=O⁢(log⁡n)subscript𝛾𝑛𝑂𝑛\gamma_{n}=O(\log n)italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ), then 𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1)J𝝅~−Jπ=O⁢(log⁡nn)→n→∞0subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1superscript𝐽bold-~𝝅superscript𝐽𝜋𝑂𝑛𝑛superscript→→𝑛0\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1})}J^{\bm{\tilde{\pi}}}% -J^{\pi}=O(\frac{\log n}{\sqrt{n}})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle n\to\infty}}{{\to}}0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_ARG ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG → end_ARG start_ARG italic_n → ∞ end_ARG end_RELOP 0. While these performance guarantees only hold in expectation, they arise from minimal assumptions, mostly regarding the policy class and the perturbation noise, and can thus be applied to arbitrary MDPs.

Appendix C Practical Objective

Following up on the approximations reported in Section 4.2, we present the empirical estimate of the objective that is used through experiments. In particular, we show how the expectations in Equation 2 may be approximated with finite samples. The original criterion is expressed as

cn=arg⁢minc′∈𝒞⁡ϕn⁢(c′)=arg⁢minc′∈𝒞⁢𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1),τ′∼𝝉⁢(c′)c∼μc,(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)∑t=0H−1ℋ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c)∣c′,τ′,c1:n−1,τ1:n−1).subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptargminsuperscript𝑐′𝒞subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛superscript𝑐′subscriptargminsuperscript𝑐′𝒞subscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1similar-tosuperscript𝜏′𝝉superscript𝑐′formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑐subscript𝜇𝑐similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℋconditional𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝜏′subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscript𝜏:1𝑛1c_{n}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}}\phi_{n}(c^{\prime})=% \operatorname*{arg\,min}_{c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\begin% {subarray}{c}\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau}(c_{1:n-1}),\;\tau^{\prime}\sim\bm{\tau}% (c^{\prime})\\ c\sim\mu_{c},\;(s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}% \mathcal{H}(\bm{\pi}(s_{t},c)\mid c^{\prime},\tau^{\prime},c_{1:n-1},\tau_{1:n% -1}).italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (86)

An empirical estimate can be derived as follows:

ϕn⁢(c′)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛superscript𝑐′\displaystyle\phi_{n}(c^{\prime})italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =𝔼τ1:n−1∼𝝉⁢(c1:n−1),τ′∼𝝉⁢(c′)c∼μc,(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)∑t=0H−1ℋ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c)∣c′,τ′,c1:n−1,τ1:n−1)absentsubscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝜏:1𝑛1𝝉subscript𝑐:1𝑛1similar-tosuperscript𝜏′𝝉superscript𝑐′formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑐subscript𝜇𝑐similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℋconditional𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝜏′subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscript𝜏:1𝑛1\displaystyle=\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\begin{subarray}{c}\tau_{1:n-1}\sim\bm{\tau% }(c_{1:n-1}),\;\tau^{\prime}\sim\bm{\tau}(c^{\prime})\\ c\sim\mu_{c},\;(s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}% \mathcal{H}(\bm{\pi}(s_{t},c)\mid c^{\prime},\tau^{\prime},c_{1:n-1},\tau_{1:n% -1})= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (87)
≈(i)𝔼τ′∼𝝉⁢(c′)c∼μc,(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)∑t=0H−1ℋ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c)∣c′,τ′,c1:n−1,τ^1:n−1)superscript𝑖absentsubscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝜏′𝝉superscript𝑐′formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑐subscript𝜇𝑐similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℋconditional𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝜏′subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscript^𝜏:1𝑛1\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(i)}}{{\approx}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{% \begin{subarray}{c}\tau^{\prime}\sim\bm{\tau}(c^{\prime})\\ c\sim\mu_{c},\;(s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}% \mathcal{H}(\bm{\pi}(s_{t},c)\mid c^{\prime},\tau^{\prime},c_{1:n-1},\hat{\tau% }_{1:n-1})start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≈ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_i ) end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c ∼ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (88)
≈(i⁢i)1|𝒞^|⁢∑c∈𝒞^𝔼τ′∼𝝉⁢(c′)(s0,…)∼𝝉⁢(c)∑t=0H−1ℋ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c)∣c′,τ′,c1:n−1,τ1:n−1)superscript𝑖𝑖absent1^𝒞subscript𝑐^𝒞subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝜏′𝝉superscript𝑐′similar-tosubscript𝑠0…𝝉𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℋconditional𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝜏′subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscript𝜏:1𝑛1\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(ii)}}{{\approx}}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{\hat{C% }}|}\sum_{c\in\mathcal{\hat{C}}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\begin{subarray}{c}\tau^{% \prime}\sim\bm{\tau}(c^{\prime})\\ (s_{0},\dots)\sim\bm{\tau}(c)\end{subarray}}\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}\mathcal{H}(\bm{% \pi}(s_{t},c)\mid c^{\prime},\tau^{\prime},c_{1:n-1},\tau_{1:n-1})start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≈ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_i italic_i ) end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c ∈ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ) ∼ bold_italic_τ ( italic_c ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H ( bold_italic_π ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) ∣ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (89)

≈(i⁢i⁢i)1|𝒞^|⁢(n−1)2⁢∑c∈𝒞^∑τ′∈τ^1:n−1(s0,…)∈τ^1:n−1w⁢(τ′,c′)⁢w⁢((s0,…),c)⁢∑t=0H−1ℋ⁢(𝝅⁢(st,c)∣c′,τ′,c1:n−1,τ1:n−1),superscript𝑖𝑖𝑖absent1^𝒞superscript𝑛12subscript𝑐^𝒞subscriptsuperscript𝜏′subscript^𝜏:1𝑛1subscript𝑠0…subscript^𝜏:1𝑛1𝑤superscript𝜏′superscript𝑐′𝑤subscript𝑠0…𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1ℋconditional𝝅subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscript𝑐′superscript𝜏′subscript𝑐:1𝑛1subscript𝜏:1𝑛1\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(iii)}}{{\approx}}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{\hat{% C}}|(n-1)^{2}}\sum_{c\in\mathcal{\hat{C}}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\tau^{% \prime}\in\hat{\tau}_{1:n-1}\\ (s_{0},\dots)\in\hat{\tau}_{1:n-1}\end{subarray}}w(\tau^{\prime},c^{\prime})w(% (s_{0},\dots),c)\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}\!\mathcal{H}(\bm{\pi}(s_{t},c)\mid c^{\prime}% ,\tau^{\prime},c_{1:n-1},\tau_{1:n-1}),start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≈ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_i italic_i italic_i ) end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG | ( italic_n - where (i) uses a single sample to estimate the expectation over past trajectories, (ii) uses a sample-based approximation to the target task distribution μcsubscript𝜇𝑐\mu_{c}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and (iii) uses the importance sampling trick introduced in Section 4.2, with w⁢(τ,c)=(n−1)⁢∏t=0H−1𝝅~⁢(at|st,c)∑i=0n−1∏t=0H−1𝝅~⁢(at|st,ci)𝑤𝜏𝑐𝑛1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡0𝐻1bold-~𝝅conditionalsubscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡0𝐻1bold-~𝝅conditionalsubscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖w(\tau,c)=\frac{(n-1)\prod_{t=0}^{H-1}\bm{\tilde{\pi}}(a_{t}|s_{t},c)}{\sum_{i% =0}^{n-1}\prod_{t=0}^{H-1}\bm{\tilde{\pi}}(a_{t}|s_{t},c_{i})}italic_w ( italic_τ , italic_c ) = divide start_ARG ( italic_n - 1 ) ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overbold_~ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG. This final approximate objective does not involve expectations, and can be efficiently computed. The complexity of evaluating the criterion for a single task c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT scales linearly with the number of samples in 𝒞^^𝒞\mathcal{\hat{C}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG and quadratically with the number of rounds n𝑛nitalic_n. However, the dependency on the number of rounds can be removed by evaluating the second sum over a fixed number of trajectories sampled among τ1:n−1subscript𝜏:1𝑛1\tau_{1:n-1}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ensuring that the complexity does not depend on the round.

Appendix D Additional results for AMF-GP

Figure 3 only reports full return curves for two representative pre-training settings, namely those involving 6/126126/126 / 12 and 12/12121212/1212 / 12 demonstrated tasks. We here report full results for each task allocation, spanning from 1/121121/121 / 12 to 12/12121212/1212 / 12 demonstrated tasks. For each setting, we report both average multi-task return and average policy entropy curves.

Appendix E Additional results for AMF-NN

Results in Figure 4 are computed over two representative pre-training distributions: one allocating pre-training demonstrations uniformly over all tasks, the other one only demonstrating the first two tasks. We report these results again, and compare them with those for several other pre-training distributions. In particular, we evaluate a family of skewed priors which are only trained on one or two tasks. Results are reported for FrankaKitchen in Figure 9 and for Metaworld in Figure 10, and are consistent with patterns observed in Figure 4.

Moreover, we also report an ablation over the choice of batch size for Metaworld in Figure 11, thus complementing the one reported in Section 5.3. We observe a slight upward trend favoring larger batch size in the case of an uniform prior, but smaller batches remain overall desirable.

Appendix F Uncertainty ablation

Section 5.4 evaluates alternative uncertainty quantification schemes in FrankaKitchen for two pre-training distributions. This Section extends these results to include results for Metaworld, and for several other pre-training settings (see Figures 12 and 13). Results are consistent with those so far reported, suggesting that loss gradient embeddings are an important component for the empirical performance of AMF-NN.

Appendix G Mitigating forgetting

The ability of neural networks to adapt to shifts in training distribution while retaining information is an important object of interest in lifelong and continual learning (Wang et al., 2024). In general, learned models display a trade-off between their ability to integrate novel information, and their memory of previously observed training samples. Arguably, common neural network architectures can easily fit new data (save for loss of plasticity (Lyle et al., 2023)), but are known to forget previous information, often catastrophically. This problem is of utmost relevance in our setting, in which the pre-trained network is not just leveraged as a useful initialization, but may already capable of solving some tasks. Hence, the fine-tuning procedure should be careful not to disrupt this ability.

Several methods aimed at mitigating forgetting can be traced back to rehearsal (Riemer et al., 2019; Chaudhry et al., 2019) and regularization (Kirkpatrick et al., 2017) strategies. While rehearsal approaches are often effective, they also require access to pre-training data, which is unrealistic in our setting. Hence we consider two common regularization technique, namely L2-regularization to the pre-trained weights, and EWC (Kirkpatrick et al., 2017). The latter can be seen as a more nuanced version of the former, which adaptively scales the regularization strength according to the curvature of the loss landscape. Unfortunately, we found both methods to be insufficient in our setting, as reported in Figure 14. When coupled with large regularization weights, their asymptotical performance is significantly limited. When regularization weights are too low, they recover the performance of a naive baseline. Intermediate values were found to interpolate between the two behaviors, without addressing the forgetting issue. While less scalable, we found hard parameter isolation to be the only effective solution amongst the one we tested. As mitigating forgetting in neural network is an orthogonal direction to the main topic of this work, we adopt this solution, and expect that further developments in continual learning will be applicable in our setting.

Appendix H Criterion vs returns

As a didactic example, we evaluate the criterion optimized by AMF-GP in a particular instance. We adopt the settings presented in Section 5.1, and pre-train a GP policy by providing 50 demonstrations in the 2D integrator environment, uniformly sampled among tasks in the top half of the target circle. We represent the task space along one dimension, and plot the smoothed pre-training distribution on the top of Figure 15. The second row of the Figure displays the evaluation of the criterion in Equation 2 for 100 tasks uniformly sampled across the entire task space. By comparison with the plot above, it is evident that the criterion is significantly lower for tasks that have not yet been demonstrated. These tasks are also those that, if demonstrated, would lead to a greater increase in multi-task performance after fine-tuning, as reported in the bottom row of Figure 15. In this instance, it’s easy to see that the criterion leads to selection of tasks which have not been demonstrated sufficiently, and that will thus lead to greater policy performance.

Appendix I Implementation Details

In order to ease reproducibility, we open-source our codebase on the project’s anonymous website.​444sites.google.com/active-multitask-finetuning Furthermore, we describe several implementation details in the following sections.

I.1 Metrics

All metrics are reported in the form of their mean and the 90% simple bootstrap confidence intervals over 10101010 random seeds.

I.2 GP settings

In GP settings (5.1), each expert demonstration involves 5555 steps, is corrupted with Gaussian noise and collected by a scripted policy. As the task space is continuous, the criterion is simply optimized via uniform random shooting, with a budget of 100100100100. Multi-task returns are averaged over 20202020 episodes per task.

I.3 Neural network settings

I.3.1 Environments

We evaluate AMF-NN across three environments, namely FrankaKitchen, Metaworld and WidowX. For the first two, demonstrations are 50505050 steps, while for the latter they involve 100100100100 steps. In FrankaKitchen, demonstrations are provided by Kumar et al. (2024), and collected by trained SAC agents. In Metaworld, demostrations are instead collected by the scripted policies provided (Yu et al., 2020). Finally, in WidowX successful trajectories are collected by Octo-small (Octo Model Team et al., 2024) itself and filtered according to success labels, in an instance of self-supervised distillation. Furthermore, in the case of WidowX, the initial position of the object is not randomized, as we found this to result in very inconsistent performance for the data collection policy. In the first two environments, 25252525 attempts for each task are evaluated, while the evaluation for WidowX involves 50505050 attempts.

I.3.2 Behavior cloning

The policy is parameterized via a deterministic MLP with 2222 layers and 256256256256 units per layer, with layer normalization (Ba, 2016). Task conditioning are image embedding extracted by R3M (Nair et al., 2022a). Policies are pre-trained for 500500500500 epochs with batch size of 128128128128, learning rate of 1.e−4formulae-sequence1𝑒41.e-41 . italic_e - 4 using the Adam optimizer (Kingma, 2014).

I.3.3 Importance sampling weights

In GP setting, importance weights are computed from the Gaussian policy distribution, and log-probabilities are clipped to the range [−12,0]120[-12,0][ - 12 , 0 ]. In NN settings, for deterministic policies, we interpret the policy’s output as the mean of a Gaussian with fixed standard deviation σ=1.0𝜎1.0\sigma=1.0italic_σ = 1.0, and only clip log-probabilities for numerical stability. In experiments involving pre-trained Octo policies, we evaluated two solutions. One option consisted of fitting a Gaussian distribution through maximum likelihood methods to samples from the diffusion policy, and was found to underperform. We thus treat the Octo policy as strictly deterministic: with continuous action spaces, this simplifies importance sampling weights to w⁢(c,τ)=1𝑤𝑐𝜏1w(c,\tau)=1italic_w ( italic_c , italic_τ ) = 1 in case τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a demonstration provided exactly for task c𝑐citalic_c, and 00 otherwise. We note that this solution cannot be used to evaluate the criterion on yet unobserved tasks, but remains feasible when tasks are finite and few.

I.3.4 AMF

Each fine-tuning round involves 3000300030003000 gradient steps, each with a batch size of 128128128128. We warm-start each algorithm by collecting the first |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}|| caligraphic_C | demonstrations uniformly, as mentioned in Section 4.2. In the case of loss-gradient embeddings, we found it to be beneficial to use a separate copy of the policy for task selection, which is not trained on these initial trajectories (which thus can be seen as a small “validation” set). As these demonstrations are not selected according to the criterion, to avoid unwanted updates of pre-training weights, they are only added to the training set once the algorithm selects a task belonging to the same partition of the task space, as defined by parameter isolation.

Appendix J Useful inequalities

Lemma 8.

If a,b∈(0,M]𝑎𝑏0𝑀a,b\in(0,M]italic_a , italic_b ∈ ( 0 , italic_M ] for some M>0𝑀0M>0italic_M > 0 and b≥a𝑏𝑎b\geq aitalic_b ≥ italic_a then

b−a≤M⋅log⁡(ba).𝑏𝑎⋅𝑀𝑏𝑎b-a\leq M\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right).italic_b - italic_a ≤ italic_M ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) .

If additionally, a≥M′𝑎superscript𝑀′a\geq M^{\prime}italic_a ≥ italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some M′>0superscript𝑀′0M^{\prime}>0italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 then

b−a≥M′⋅log⁡(ba).𝑏𝑎⋅superscript𝑀′𝑏𝑎b-a\geq M^{\prime}\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right).italic_b - italic_a ≥ italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) .
Proof.

Let f⁢(x)⁢=def⁢log⁡x𝑓𝑥def𝑥f(x)\overset{\text{def}}{=}\log xitalic_f ( italic_x ) overdef start_ARG = end_ARG roman_log italic_x. By the mean value theorem, there exists c∈(a,b)𝑐𝑎𝑏c\in(a,b)italic_c ∈ ( italic_a , italic_b ) such that

1c=f′⁢(c)=f⁢(b)−f⁢(a)b−a=log⁡b−log⁡ab−a=log⁡(ba)b−a.1𝑐superscript𝑓′𝑐𝑓𝑏𝑓𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎\frac{1}{c}=f^{\prime}(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}=\frac{\log b-\log a}{b-a}=% \frac{\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right)}{b-a}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_c end_ARG = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) = divide start_ARG italic_f ( italic_b ) - italic_f ( italic_a ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_b - italic_a end_ARG = divide start_ARG roman_log italic_b - roman_log italic_a end_ARG start_ARG italic_b - italic_a end_ARG = divide start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_b - italic_a end_ARG .

Thus,

b−a=c⋅log⁡(ba)<M⋅log⁡(ba).𝑏𝑎⋅𝑐𝑏𝑎⋅𝑀𝑏𝑎b-a=c\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right)<M\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right).italic_b - italic_a = italic_c ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) < italic_M ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) .

Under the additional condition that a≥M′𝑎superscript𝑀′a\geq M^{\prime}italic_a ≥ italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we obtain

b−a=c⋅log⁡(ba)>M′⋅log⁡(ba).𝑏𝑎⋅𝑐𝑏𝑎⋅superscript𝑀′𝑏𝑎b-a=c\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}\right)>M^{\prime}\cdot\log\left(\frac{b}{a}% \right).italic_b - italic_a = italic_c ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) > italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) .

∎

Lemma 9.

Let us consider two spaces X∈ℝn𝑋superscriptℝ𝑛X\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_X ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Y∈ℝm𝑌superscriptℝ𝑚Y\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_Y ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and a conditional distribution p:X→Δ⁢(Y):𝑝→𝑋Δ𝑌p:X\to\Delta(Y)italic_p : italic_X → roman_Δ ( italic_Y ) whose support supp(p(⋅|x))\text{supp}(p(\cdot|x))supp ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ) is bounded by a ball of radius ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ for all x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X, that is

maxyl,yh∈suppp(⋅|x)⁡‖yh−yl‖2≤ϵ.\max_{y_{l},y_{h}\in\text{supp}p(\cdot|x)}\|y_{h}-y_{l}\|_{2}\leq\epsilon.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ supp italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ .

For all (x,x′)⊆X𝑥superscript𝑥′𝑋(x,x^{\prime})\subseteq X( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊆ italic_X, y∼p(⋅|x)y\sim p(\cdot|x)italic_y ∼ italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) and y′∼p(⋅|x′)y^{\prime}\sim p(\cdot|x^{\prime})italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) it holds that

∥y−y′∥2≤𝒲(p(⋅|x),p(⋅|x′))+2ϵ,\|y-y^{\prime}\|_{2}\leq\mathcal{W}(p(\cdot|x),p(\cdot|x^{\prime}))+2\epsilon,∥ italic_y - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ caligraphic_W ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) , italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + 2 italic_ϵ ,

where K𝐾Kitalic_K denotes the Wasserstein 1111-distance.

Proof.
‖y−y′‖norm𝑦superscript𝑦′\displaystyle\|y-y^{\prime}\|∥ italic_y - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤maxy∈supp(p(⋅|x))y′∈supp(p(⋅|x′))⁡‖y−y′‖2\displaystyle\leq\max_{\begin{subarray}{c}y\in\text{supp}(p(\cdot|x))\\ y^{\prime}\in\text{supp}(p(\cdot|x^{\prime}))\end{subarray}}\|y-y^{\prime}\|_{2}≤ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_y ∈ supp ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ supp ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_y - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (93)
≤(i)miny∈supp(p(⋅|x))y′∈supp(p(⋅|x′))⁡‖y−y′‖2+2⁢ϵ\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(i)}}{{\leq}}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}y\in% \text{supp}(p(\cdot|x))\\ y^{\prime}\in\text{supp}(p(\cdot|x^{\prime}))\end{subarray}}\|y-y^{\prime}\|_{% 2}+2\epsilonstart_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≤ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_i ) end_ARG end_RELOP roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_y ∈ supp ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ supp ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_y - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_ϵ (94)
≤(i⁢i)𝒲(p(⋅|x),p(⋅|x′))+2ϵ,\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(ii)}}{{\leq}}\mathcal{W}(p(\cdot|x),p(% \cdot|x^{\prime}))+2\epsilon,start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≤ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_i italic_i ) end_ARG end_RELOP caligraphic_W ( italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x ) , italic_p ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + 2 italic_ϵ , (95)

where (i) follows from the triangle inequality, and (2) is due to the fact that the integral of the distance between two points in Y𝑌Yitalic_Y for any coupling is greater than the minimum distance. ∎
